meta_data.title: Expanding the Paradigm of Image Similarity Prediction through Context-sensitive Science
affiliations: Computer Science Department, University of Techland
meta_data.abstract: Image similarity has been a critical concept in computer vision for decades. Recent advances in deep learning offer new potentials for estimating image similarity, often leveraged in content-based retrieval. Despite these advancements, aligning these embeddings with human perception still poses challenges. This paper re-examines the fundamental problem of image similarity with a novel dataset of 30k labeled triples. Through the methods of context-sensitive training and ensemble modeling, we present a systematic approach to improving model competency across varied contexts. Our experimental findings highlight the potential of this method in achieving superior semantic alignment over conventional approaches.

relate work.related papers: Wang et al. discussed feature extractors focused primarily on visual attributes, whereas Deselaers et al. explored the connection between visual and semantic aspects. Movshovitz-Attias et al. and Aziere et al. proposed methods to manage data space challenges using proxies and ensemble models.
relate work.comparisons with related methods: Unlike existing datasets such as BAPPS or NIGHTS, our dataset CoSIS introduces an unbiased selection of candidate images, overcoming previous datasetsâ€™ limitations of restricted candidate selection. Similarly, our approach diverges from standard proxy methods by integrating context-sensitivity directly into model tunings.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: This paper explores the limitations of current image similarity models and proposes a new context-sensitive approach to improve image model alignment with human perception.
high_level_summary.research purpose: Enhance image similarity predictions through context-sensitive training, potentially offering better alignment with human semantic understanding.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Despite advances in deep embeddings, aligning them with human perception in image similarity remains challenging, primarily due to the lack of contextual understanding in these models.
high_level_summary.method summary: We introduce a novel dataset composed of 30k context-sensitive triples, develop context-sensitive models to improve local performance, and apply ensemble methods to enhance global accuracy.
high_level_summary.conclusion: Our findings illustrate that context-sensitive ensemble models significantly enhance semantic similarity prediction, outperforming existing methods in terms of aligning with human judgments.

Method.description: The proposed method focuses on training context-sensitive models (CS models) leveraging our curated dataset and utilizing ensemble approaches to refine model accuracy.
Method.problem formultaion: The primary challenge is the misalignment between machine-learned embeddings and human semantic evaluations, aggravated by the absence of context in current models.
Method.model: Our framework includes training individual CS models on respective data clusters and forming ensemble models to improve overall model prediction capabilities.
Method.theoretical analysis: The theoretical benefits of CS models lie in their ability to model human-like decision-making processes by acknowledging context-dependent similarities.
Method.complexity: Our methodology is computationally efficient, requiring context-specific model training yet providing enhanced generalization across various domains.
Method.algorithm step: 1. Selection of reference images 2. Extraction and partitioning of context-sensitive triples 3. Training of CS models 4. Evaluation using validation and testing datasets 5. Development of ensemble models from individual CS models

Experiments.evaluation metric: Accuracy in predicting the closer candidate image to a reference image
Experiments.setup: We utilized several computational models including ViT and ResNet with an emphasis on training context-sensitive models using context clusters from our dataset.
Experiments.results: The context-sensitive (CS) models outperformed baselines in local contexts, and ensemble models surpassed baselines in testing on random triples, achieving higher global accuracy.
Experiments.performance: Our ensemble methods showed a performance increase of up to 10% over existing baselines on random unseen triples, validating their effectiveness.
Experiments.analysis: The results suggest that ensemble models constructed from context-sensitive sub-models better capture the nuances of human perception of image similarity.

conclusion.summary: This research demonstrates the efficacy of context-sensitive modeling in improving the semantic validity of image similarity models.
conclusion.future work: Future studies could investigate broader applications of CS models and seek further integration with human perceptual modeling in AI.
